Il vous faudra probablement abaisser de temps en temps le financement de la recherche pour éviter la faillite de votre civilisation.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Coût d'entretien des unités :[\BOLD] selon le régime politique adopté, vous risquez de devoir payer un "coût d'entretien" pour chacune de vos [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unités[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Modernisation des unités :[\BOLD] les [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]progrès technologiques[\LINK] peuvent vous permettre de moderniser vos unités existantes (transformer par exemple un archer en arbalétrier). Ceci a un coût.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Accélérer la construction :[\BOLD] le régime du [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]suffrage universel[\LINK] vous permet d'utiliser votre or pour "accélérer" la construction d'une unité ou d'un bâtiment.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatie :[\BOLD] vous pouvez dépenser votre or dans le cadre d'actions [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomatiques[\LINK]. Même une civilisation ennemie acceptera souvent de faire ce que vous voulez, pour peu que vous y mettiez le prix.[PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez voir un résumé de toutes les dépenses actuelles de votre civilisation en ouvrant l'écran du Conseiller financier avec la touche F3.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Régimes et richesse[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]régime[\LINK] de votre civilisation influe sur vos recettes et vos dépenses. Certains régimes, par exemple, rémunèrent vos échanges pacifiques, quand d'autres diminuent le coût d'entretien de votre armée.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Manquer d'or[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Si votre civilisation ne peut plus payer ses dépenses, vos villes lancent des mouvements de "grève". Elles cessent de produire des unités et des bâtiments jusqu'à ce que vos finances s'améliorent. De plus, vous risquez de perdre les unités et les bâtiments dont vous ne pouvez plus payer l'entretien. Lorsque vos villes sont en grève, il est très important de rééquilibrer vos comptes le plus rapidement possible.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Mauvaise gestion précoce[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez rencontrer au début d'une partie des difficultés financières. Cela se produit généralement quand vous créez de nombreuses villes et unités sans avoir construit préalablement les bâtiments et améliorations nécessaires pour que vos villes puissent supporter le coût de votre expansion. Vos dépenses excèdent alors nettement vos revenus et votre trésor se vide rapidement. Il y a de nombreuses choses à faire pour régler le problème :[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Villages isolés :[\BOLD] si des villages isolés se trouvent à proximité, envoyez une de vos unités, ils vous paieront peut-être un tribut (cela reste néanmoins une solution très provisoire !).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diminuer votre budget recherche :[\BOLD] réduisez la quantité d'or dépensée chaque tour pour la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]recherche technologique[\LINK] en vous servant du bouton situé en haut à gauche de l'écran.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construire des améliorations :[\BOLD] construisez des [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]Cottages[\LINK] et autres [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]améliorations[\LINK] qui exploitent les ressources rentables à l'intérieur de vos [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]frontières[\LINK] : des mines pour l'or et l'argent, des campements pour la fourrure et l'ivoire, etc. Construisez aussi des routes pour relier vos villes à ces ressources.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Construire des bâtiments :[\BOLD] construisez des [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]tribunaux[\LINK] pour réduire le coût d'entretien de vos villes, et des [LINK=BUILDING_MARKETS]marchés[\LINK] pour augmenter leur revenu. Si vous ne pouvez pas encore construire ces bâtiments, orientez votre [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]recherche[\LINK] vers les technologies qui les rendront disponibles. Ne pas construire ces bâtiments assez tôt est une erreur classique des débutants à Civilization IV ![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Produire de la richesse :[\BOLD] si votre niveau technologique le permet, vous pouvez ordonner à vos villes de produire de la richesse plutôt que des unités ou des bâtiments.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mettre l'accent sur le revenu :[\BOLD] ordonnez à vos villes de [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]"mettre l'accent sur le revenu"[\LINK] en ce qui concerne l'exploitation des terres environnantes. Attention, cependant, à vérifier les choix des gouverneurs des villes. Ce ne seront pas forcément les mêmes que les vôtres.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Modifier les régimes :[\BOLD] consultez l'écran des [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]régimes[\LINK] pour voir si vous ne pouvez pas réduire le "coût d'entretien du régime" en choisissant des régimes moins coûteux.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Détruire des unités :[\BOLD] éliminez les unités militaires inutiles. Détruisez vos colons plutôt que de fonder des villes que vous ne pourrez pas entretenir.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatie :[\BOLD] en fonction de votre niveau technologique, vous pourrez peut-être obtenir de l'or de vos voisins, en le leur réclamant.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Capturer des villes ennemies :[\BOLD] capturer une ville et piller les améliorations peut rapporter gros.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Abandonner des villes :[\BOLD] en dernier recours, vous pouvez abandonner des villes qui vous coûtent trop cher. Vous pouvez les donner à d'autres civilisations, via la diplomatie, ou simplement enlever toutes les unités militaires et croiser les doigts pour qu'un barbare s'en empare (cependant, si les choses vont aussi mal que ça, vous pouvez aussi considérer l'option ("Commencer une nouvelle partie").
TEXT.German: [H1]Wohlstand[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Die Geschichte hat uns immer wieder gezeigt, wie wichtig es ist, seinen Wohlstand zu wahren. Im 16. Jahrhundert hatte Spanien Zugang zu den fast unerschöpflichen Gold- und Silbervorkommen Zentral- und Südamerikas. Und doch war Spanien ab einem gewissen Zeitpunkt aufgrund von Korruption und Misswirtschaft nicht in der Lage, Schiffe und Soldaten zum Schutz seiner Kolonien zu finanzieren. Oder ein anderes Beispiel: Nach dem 1. Weltkrieg war Deutschland bankrott und hatte alle Kolonien verloren. Nur 20 Jahre später sollte es mit der größten und schlagkräftigsten Armee aller Zeiten Europa in den Abgrund stürzen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Wohlstand ist eine wichtige Komponente von Civilization IV. Ist Ihre Zivilisation wohlhabend, wird sie wachsen und gedeihen. Gehen Sie verschwenderisch mit Ihrem Geld um, sind Ihre Tage gezählt.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2] Aktueller Wohlstand[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Die Wohlstandsanzeige im Hauptbildschirm zeigt Ihren aktuellen Wohlstand an. Dies ist in der Regel eine positive Zahl oder 0. Die Zahl neben der Wohlstandsanzeige zeigt den aktuellen Zuwachs oder Verlust an Wohlstand pro Runde an.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wirtschaft und Wohlstand[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Der Wohlstand Ihrer Städte wird von Ihren Investitionen in die [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Forschung[\LINK] und die [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Kultur[\LINK] beeinflusst. Wenden Sie beispielsweise 70%% Ihrer Einkünfte für die Wissenschaft und 10%% für die Kultur auf, werden 20%% Ihrer Wirtschaft in Wohlstand umgewandelt.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wohlstand vergrößern[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Stadt-Wohlstand:[\BOLD]Ihre Städte erzeugen Wohlstand, wenn sie Geländefelder innerhalb des [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Stadtgebiets[\LINK] bearbeiten und wertvolle [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Ressourcen[\LINK], wie Gold, Silber und Wein, besitzen. [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Modernisierungen[\LINK], wie Hütten oder Minen, können den Wohlstand einer Stadt deutlich erhöhen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Stammesdörfer:[\BOLD] Betritt eine Ihrer Einheiten ein Stammesdorf, geben Ihnen die Dorfbewohner als Tribut möglicherweise etwas Gold.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Eroberung und Plünderung:[\BOLD]Wenn Sie feindliche bzw. barbarische Städte erobern, erhalten Sie sehr viel Gold. Plündern Sie [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Modernisierungen[\LINK], ist Ihre Beute erheblich kleiner.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Große Händler:[\BOLD] Bringt eine Ihrer Städte einen [LINK=UNIT_MERCHANT]Großen Händler[\LINK] hervor, können Sie diesen auf eine Handelsmission schicken, um Ihre Goldeinnahmen zu erhöhen. Das Gold wird anschließend in Ihre Schatzkammer gebracht.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatie:[\BOLD] Sie können Ihren Wohlstand auch mithilfe der [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomatie[\LINK] vergrößern, indem Sie Waren kaufen und verkaufen oder mit Ressourcen handeln.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Investition des Wohlstands[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Stadtunterhalt:[\BOLD] Der Unterhalt Ihrer Städte kostet in jeder Runde etwas Gold. Die Summe ist von der Zahl und der Größe Ihrer Städte abhängig. Außerdem wirkt sich die Entfernung einer Stadt zum [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palast[\LINK] auf die Kosten aus.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Staatsunterhalt:[\BOLD] Für viele [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Staatsformen[\LINK] fallen ebenfalls Unterhaltskosten an. Einige Staatsformen sind kostspieliger als andere. Dies sollten Sie bei der Auswahl stets im Hinterkopf behalten.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Inflation:[\BOLD] Im Laufe des Spiels wird der Unterhalt Ihres Reiches aufgrund der einsetzenden Inflation immer teurer. Bekämpfen Sie die Inflation, indem Sie mehr Wohlstand generieren ... das ist die einzige Möglichkeit![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Forschung:[\BOLD] Sie investieren in jeder Runde Geld in die [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]technologische Forschung[\LINK] Ihrer Zivilisation. Um den drohenden Staatsbankrott zu verhindern, müssen Sie Ihre Forschungen im Laufe des Spiels möglicherweise drastisch einschränken.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unterhalt von Einheiten:[\BOLD] Abhängig von Ihrer aktuellen Staatsform müssen Sie möglicherweise Unterhaltskosten für Ihre [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Einheiten[\LINK] abführen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Modernisierung von Einheiten:[\BOLD] Haben Sie eine Einheit gebaut, können Sie diese mithilfe [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]fortschrittlicher Technologien[\LINK] modernisieren. Auf diese Weise wird beispielsweise aus einem Bogenschützen ein Armbrustschütze. Die Modernisierung kostet allerdings Gold.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Bauvorgang beschleunigen:[BOLD] Die Staatsform [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Allgemeines Wahlrecht[\LINK] ermöglicht Ihnen, den Bau von Einheiten und Gebäuden mit Gold zu beschleunigen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatie:[\BOLD] Benutzen Sie Ihren Wohlstand, um die Räder der [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomatie[\LINK] zu ölen. Feindliche Nationen stimmen Ihren Vorschlägen im Allgemeinen zu, wenn der Preis stimmt.[PARAGRAPH:2]Drücken Sie F3, um den Finanzberater-Bildschirm zu öffnen. Hier sehen Sie alle Ausgaben Ihrer Zivilisation.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Staatsformen und Wohlstand[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Die [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Staatsform[\LINK] Ihrer Zivilisation beeinflusst die Erhöhung bzw. den Rückgang Ihres Wohlstandes entscheidend. Während Sie einige Staatsformen für den friedlichen Handel belohnen, senken andere die Kosten für den Unterhalt großer Armeen.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leere Kassen[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Kann Ihre Zivilisation die Ausgaben nicht mehr bezahlen, kommt es in Ihrer Stadt zum Streik. Die Produktion neuer Einheiten und Gebäude wird in diesem Fall eingestellt, bis sich Ihre Staatskasse erholt hat. Außerdem verlieren Sie Einheiten und Gebäude, wenn Sie diese nicht mehr finanzieren können. Streiken Ihre Städte, müssen Sie Ihre Ausgaben möglichst schnell konsolidieren.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Frühe Misswirtschaft[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Haben Sie zu viele Städte oder Einheiten gebaut, ohne die Kosten mit entsprechenden Gebäuden oder Modernisierungen zu decken, geraten Sie in finanzielle Schwierigkeiten. Allerdings können Sie sich meist selbst aus dieser misslichen Lage befreien:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Stammesdörfer:[\BOLD] Gibt es in Ihrer Nähe noch Stammesdörfer, sollten Sie diesen einen Besuch abstatten. Vielleicht erhalten Sie ja etwas Gold als Tribut.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Verringern Sie Ihr Forschungsbudget:[\BOLD] Investieren Sie mit dem Button in der linken oberen Bildschirmecke weniger Geld in die [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Forschung[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Bau von Modernisierungen:[\BOLD] Bauen Sie [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]Hütten[\LINK] und andere [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Modernisierungen[\LINK], die ertragreiche Ressourcen innerhalb Ihrer [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Grenzen[\LINK] ausbeuten (Gold- und Silberminen, Lager für Pelze und Elfenbein, usw.). Bauen Sie Straßen, um diese Ressourcen an Ihre Städte anzubinden.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Bau von Gebäuden:[\BOLD] Bauen Sie [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]Gerichtsgebäude[\LINK], um die Unterhaltskosten der jeweiligen Stadt zu senken. Mit [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]Märkten[\LINK] erhöhen sie Ihr Einkommen. Können Sie diese Gebäude nicht bauen, richten Sie Ihre [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Forschung[\LINK] auf Technologien aus, die den Bau ermöglichen. Viele unerfahrene Spieler bauen diese Gebäude nicht frühzeitig und geraten deshalb in Schwierigkeiten![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wohlstand aufbauen:[\BOLD] Wenn es Ihre Technologiestufe erlaubt, können Sie den Wohlstand Ihrer Städte mehren, anstatt Gebäude und Einheiten zu bauen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Schwerpunkt Wohlstand:[\BOLD] Setzen Sie Ihre Städte auf [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]"Schwerpunkt Wohlstand"[\LINK], wenn Sie das Land im Umkreis bearbeiten. Bedenken Sie aber, dass der Stadtverwalter einer Stadt andere Entscheidungen treffen könnte.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Staatsformen anpassen:[\BOLD] Überprüfen Sie im Bildschirm [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Staatsformen[\LINK], ob Sie durch den Wechsel der Staatsform etwas Geld sparen können.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Einheiten zerstören:[\BOLD] Neutralisieren Sie überflüssige Militäreinheiten und vernichten Sie Siedler, anstatt Städte zu bauen, deren Unterhalt Sie sich nicht leisten können.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatie:[\BOLD] Abhängig von Ihrer Technologiestufe erhalten Sie von Ihren Nachbarn Gold (durch den Handel oder gewaltsam).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Eroberung von Städten:[\BOLD] Für eroberte Städte bzw. geplünderte Modernisierungen erhalten Sie Gold![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Städte aufgeben:[BOLD] Wenn nichts mehr geht, können Sie ertraglose Städte aufgeben oder anderen Zivilisationen überlassen. Natürlich können Sie auch einfach Ihre Militäreinheiten aus einer Stadt abziehen und hoffen, dass diese von Barbaren übernommen wird. Allerdings sollten Sie in derart ausweglosen Situationen ernsthaft überlegen, ein neues Spiel zu starten.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Ricchezza[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ancora una volta, il tempo e la storia ci insegnano l'importanza di una gestione oculata della ricchezza. Nel XVI secolo, la Spagna aveva a disposizione le risorse aurifere e di argento dell'America Centrale e del Sudamerica, virtualmente infinite, ma gran parte di questo tesoro andò perduto per la corruzione e la cattiva amministrazione spagnola, che non fu in grado di finanziare navi e soldati che proteggessero i suoi possedimenti americani, lasciandoli vulnerabili agli attacchi delle nazioni nemiche e dei pirati. Alla fine della Prima Guerra Mondiale, la Germania era sull'orlo della bancarotta, e fu costretta a liberarsi delle colonie; eppure, in vent'anni acquisì così tanta ricchezza da mettere in piedi la più potente e pericolosa macchina da guerra che il mondo avesse mai conosciuto.[PARAGRAPH:2]La ricchezza è una componente molto importante di Civilization IV; gestirla in maniera adeguata farà fiorire ed espandere la tua civiltà; dilapidala ed essa si indebolirà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ricchezza corrente[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Il "contatore di ricchezza" nella schermata principale mostra la ricchezza corrente, che solitamente è un numero positivo o uguale a zero (e se non è così, la tua civiltà è in guai seri!). Il numero accanto al contatore della ricchezza mostra quanta ricchezza sta guadagnando (o perdendo) la tua civiltà in quel momento, a ogni turno.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Commercio e Ricchezza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Il quantitativo di ricchezza prodotto dalle tue città viene determinato dalla percentuale di commercio convertito in [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]ricerca[\LINK] (e, successivamente, in [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]cultura[\LINK]). La percentuale di commercio che si tramuta in ricchezza è tutto quello che non viene speso per ricerca o cultura. Ad esempio, se stai spendendo il 70%% in scienza e il 10%% in cultura, il rimanente 20%% del tuo commercio produce ricchezza.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Guadagnare Ricchezza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ricchezza della Città:[\BOLD] ognuna delle tue città genera commercio dalla lavorazione degli spazi che si trovano all'interno del suo [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Raggio d'azione[\LINK], e talune [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Risorse[\LINK] come oro, argento e incenso risultano particolarmente pregiate, quindi di grande valore. La realizzazione di [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]miglioramenti[\LINK] come villette e miniere può aumentare in maniera sensibile il commercio delle tue città, il che si traduce in una maggiore ricchezza complessiva.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Villaggi Tribali:[\BOLD] quando una delle tue unità entra in un "villaggio tribale", i suoi abitanti possono regalarti dell'oro come tributo.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Conquista delle città e saccheggio dei miglioramenti:[\BOLD] puoi ottenere una gran quantità d'oro quando conquisti una città nemica o barbara. Puoi ottenerne altro (meno, di solito) quando le tue unità [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]saccheggiano[\LINK] miglioramenti nemici/barbari.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Grandi mercanti:[\BOLD] se le tue città producono un [LINK=UNIT_MERCHANT]Grande mercante[\LINK], puoi mandarlo a commerciare in una città straniera; questo produrrà un considerevole quantitativo di denaro che entrerà a far parte delle casse dello stato della tua civiltà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomazia:[\BOLD] puoi acquisire ricchezza tramite la [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomazia[\LINK], acquistando e vendendo tecnologie, e scambiando risorse.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Spendere la Ricchezza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mantenimento della città:[\BOLD] mantenere le città costa un certo quantitativo a ogni turno; tale quantitativo aumenta con l'aumentare del numero e della dimensione delle tue città. Anche la distanza di una città dal [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]palazzo[\LINK] influisce sui costi di mantenimento.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mantenimento del governo:[\BOLD] molte [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]forme di governo[\LINK] hanno costi di mantenimento a esse associate, che costano un certo quantitativo di oro a ogni turno; alcune forme di governo sono più costose di altre, tienilo a mente quando devi sceglierle.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Inflazione:[\BOLD] con il progredire del gioco, i costi di manutenzione del tuo impero aumenteranno sempre più a causa dell'inflazione. Questo significa che altri costi si andranno ad aggiungere a quelli già previsti per ogni turno. Non puoi combattere l'inflazione se non generando una maggiore ricchezza che ne attenui gli effetti.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ricerca tecnologica:[\BOLD] spendi denaro a ogni turno per finanziare la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]ricerca tecnologica[\LINK] della tua civiltà; a un certo punto, sarà quasi certamente necessario ridurre i costi della ricerca per evitare di finire in bancarotta.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Supporto alle Unità:[\BOLD] a seconda della tua forma di governo attuale, puoi dover pagare dei "costi di supporto" per ciascuna delle [LINK=CONCEPT_UNIT]unità[\LINK] impiegate.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggiornamenti delle unità:[\BOLD] dopo aver costruito un'unità, futuri [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]avanzamenti tecnologici[\LINK] potrebbero rendere possibili degli aggiornamenti per quella unità (ad esempio, per passare da arciere a balestriere): questi aggiornamenti vanno pagati, ovviamente.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Velocizzare la costruzione:[\BOLD] la forma di governo [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Suffragio Universale[\LINK] permette di investire dell'oro per "velocizzare" la costruzione di unità ed edifici di una città.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomazia:[\BOLD] puoi investire ricchezza per ingrassare gli ingranaggi della [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomazia[\LINK] in vari modi. Le civiltà nemiche solitamente sono d'accordo nel fare quello che vuoi - a patto che il prezzo sia giusto.[PARAGRAPH:2]Puoi visualizzare le spese relative a tutte le civiltà aprendo la schermata del consigliere economico, premendo il tasto F3.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Forme di governo e ricchezza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Forma di Governo[\LINK] della tua civiltà influenza in maniera considerevole il ritmo con cui acquisti/spendi la tua ricchezza. Ad esempio, alcune forme di governo ti ricompensano se gli scambi sono pacifici, altri ti permettono di tagliare i costi di mantenimento di un esercito sterminato.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Finire i soldi[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Se la tua civiltà non può permettersi di pagare le spese, le città andranno in "sciopero": cesseranno immediatamente la produzione di unità ed edifici fino a quando le tue finanze non ti permetteranno di riprendere a pagare. In aggiunta a questo, puoi perdere unità ed edifici che non ti puoi più permettere di pagare. Quando le città scendono in piazza per scioperare, è molto importante riequilibrare entrate e uscite il prima possibile.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cattiva amministrazione della ricchezza nelle prime fasi di gioco[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Non è improbabile che ti possa trovare in serie difficoltà finanziare all'inizio della partita; questo solitamente accade perché hai costruito troppe città o unità senza prima costruire gli edifici e i miglioramenti necessari affinché le tue città potessero sopportare il peso di questa espansione. Il risultato che ottieni è che le spese superano di gran lunga le entrate, e le casse dello stato si svuotano rapidamente. Esistono diversi modi per uscire da questo pasticcio fiscale:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Villaggi tribali:[\BOLD] se ce ne sono nelle vicinanze, mandaci un'unità, potresti ricevere un tributo (ma è una soluzione molto estemporanea).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Riduci il budget per la Ricerca:[\BOLD] diminuisci la quota che spendi ogni turno per la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]ricerca tecnologica[\LINK] utilizzando il pulsante che si trova in alto a sinistra nello schermo.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Costruisci miglioramenti:[\BOLD] costruisci [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]villette[\LINK] e altri [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]miglioramenti[\LINK] che permettano di sfruttare al meglio le risorse all'interno dei tuoi [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]confini[\LINK]: miniere d'oro e argento, e così via. Costruisci strade che colleghino le tue città a queste risorse.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Costruisci Edifici:[\BOLD] edifica [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]palazzi di giustizia[\LINK] per ridurre i costi di mantenimento della città e [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]mercati[\LINK] per aumentare le entrate. Se non hai possibilità di costruirli, orienta la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Ricerca[\LINK] verso quelle tecnologie che ti faciliteranno la loro costruzione. Non riuscire a costruire quegli edifici è un problema che saranno costretti ad affrontare tutti i nuovi giocatori di Civilization IV![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Genera ricchezza:[\BOLD] se il tuo livello tecnologico te lo consente, puoi assegnare alle tue città la generazione di Ricchezza invece della costruzione di edifici o unità.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Privilegiare la produzione di ricchezza:[\BOLD] Ordina alle tue città di [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]"privilegiare la produzione di ricchezza"[\LINK] quando lavorano la terra attorno a loro. Attento, però: il governatore della città potrebbe compiere scelte diverse dalle tue.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cambia forma di governo:[\BOLD] controlla la [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]schermata politica[\LINK] per vedere se puoi ridurre i costi di mantenimento di un governo passando a uno più economico.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Distruggi le unità:[\BOLD] elimina le unità militari in eccesso; distruggi i coloni, piuttosto che creare città che non puoi permetterti.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomazia:[\BOLD] a seconda del tuo livello tecnologico, potresti riuscire a ottenere oro dai tuoi vicini - tramite scambi OPPURE con la forza.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Conquista le città nemiche:[\BOLD] di solito si ottiene un buon aumento di capitale conquistando le città nemiche o saccheggiandone i miglioramenti.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Abbandona le città:[\BOLD] se non funziona niente altro, puoi abbandonare le città in perdita. Puoi cederle ad altre civiltà tramite la diplomazia, o semplicemente rimuovere tutte le unità militari al suo interno e sperare che una civiltà Barbara la conquisti (se le cose sono messe COSI' male da dover arrivare a questo, tuttavia, non scartare del tutto l'ipotesi "Inizia una nuova partita".
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Riqueza[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Una y otra vez, la historia nos enseña la importancia de gestionar la riqueza adecuadamente. En el s. XVI, España tenía acceso a las fuentes casi inagotables de oro y plata de América Central y del Sur, aunque gran parte de ello se perdió debido a la corrupción y la mala gestión, de modo que España no pudo financiar los barcos y soldados necesarios para proteger sus posesiones en América, haciéndolas vulnerables a los ataques de naciones enemigas y piratas. Al terminar la Primera Guerra Mundial, Alemania estaba en bancarrota y había perdido sus colonias de ultramar, aunque en veinte años consiguió bastante riqueza como para construir y sostener la maquinaria militar más poderosa que el mundo había visto.[PARAGRAPH:2]La riqueza es una parte muy importante de Civilization IV. Gestiónala adecuadamente y tu civilización florecerá y prosperará; despilfárrala y tu civilización languidecerá.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2] Riqueza actual[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]El "contador de riqueza" de la pantalla principal muestra la riqueza que tienes en cada momento. Ésta suele ser una cifra positiva o cero (si no, tu civilización tiene un problema muy serio). El número situado al lado del contador de riqueza te indica cuánta riqueza está ganando (o perdiendo) tu civilización cada turno.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Comercio y riqueza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La cantidad de riqueza que producen las ciudades se determina en base al porcentaje del comercio que destinas a [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]investigación[\LINK] (y, más adelante, a [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]cultura[\LINK]). El porcentaje de comercio que se convierte en riqueza es el que no gastas en investigación y cultura. Por ejemplo, si estás gastando un 70%% en investigación y un 10%% en cultura, el 20%% restante de comercio es el que destinas a generar riqueza.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Obtener riqueza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Riqueza de la ciudad:[\BOLD] Cada una de tus ciudades genera comercio en las casillas explotadas que haya dentro de su [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]radio urbano[\LINK] y hay ciertos [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]recursos[\LINK] (como el oro, la plata y el incienso) que son especialmente valiosos. Construir [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]mejoras[\LINK] como villas y minas aumenta drásticamente el comercio de las ciudades, lo que se traduce en más riqueza.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aldeas tribales:[\BOLD] Cuando una de tus unidades entre en una "aldea tribal", puede que los aldeanos te den oro como tributo.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Capturar ciudades y saquear mejoras:[\BOLD] Puedes ganar oro a montones cuando captures una ciudad enemiga o bárbara. Puedes obtener una cantidad de oro (bastante más pequeña) cuando tus unidades [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]saqueen[\LINK] las mejoras de los enemigos o bárbaros.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Grandes mercaderes:[\BOLD] Si tus ciudades crean un [LINK=UNIT_MERCHANT]gran mercader[\LINK], podrás enviarlo en misión comercial a una ciudad extranjera. Eso generará una gran cantidad de oro que irá a parar al tesoro de tu civilización.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacia:[\BOLD] Puedes adquirir riqueza mediante la [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomacia[\LINK] gracias a la compra y la venta de tecnologías y al intercambio de recursos.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Gastar riqueza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mantenimiento de las ciudades:[\BOLD] Mantener las ciudades te cuesta una cierta cantidad cada turno, y dicho coste crece a medida que aumentan la cantidad y tamaño de tus ciudades. La distancia que separa una ciudad del [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]palacio[\LINK] también afecta a su coste de mantenimiento.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mantenimiento de los principios:[\BOLD] Todos los [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]principios[\LINK] tienen un coste de mantenimiento asociado que te supondrá el desembolso de una cantidad de oro cada turno. Algunos principios son mucho más caros que otros, así que tenlo en cuenta cuando los escojas.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Inflación:[\BOLD] A medida que avance la partida de Civilization IV el mantenimiento de tu imperio se irá encareciendo debido a un proceso económico conocido como "inflación". Ésta le costará a tu civilización una cantidad determinada de oro cada turno, además de todos los otros costes. La única forma que tienes de luchar contra la inflación es generar más riqueza para contrarrestar sus efectos.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Investigación tecnológica:[\BOLD] Cada turno gastas dinero para financiar la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]investigación tecnológica[\LINK] de tu civilización. En cierto momento probablemente tengas que reducir el nivel de investigación para impedir que tu civilización vaya a la bancarrota.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Abastecimiento de las unidades:[\BOLD] Según los principios que hayas adoptado, puede que se te exija pagar "costes de abastecimiento" por cada [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unidad[\LINK] que tengas en juego.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Modernizar unidades:[\BOLD] Después de que construyas una unidad, los futuros [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]avances tecnológicos[\LINK] puede que te permitan modernizarla (por ejemplo, de un arquero a un ballestero). Debes pagar tales modernizaciones.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Acelerar la construcción: [BOLD]El principio de [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]sufragio universal[\LINK] te permite acelerar la construcción de edificios o unidades en la ciudad.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacia:[\BOLD] Puedes emplear la riqueza de muchas maneras para engrasar los engranajes de la [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomacia[\LINK]. Normalmente, las civilizaciones enemigas suelen acceder a lo que quieres... si pagas el precio oportuno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Puedes acceder a un visor con todos los gastos que tenga tu civilización en cada momento si abres la pantalla del consejero financiero con la tecla F3.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Principios y riqueza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]principios[\LINK] que haya adoptado tu civilización afectarán mucho al ritmo con el que ganes o gastes la riqueza. Por ejemplo, algunos te recompensan con un intercambio pacífico, mientras que otros reducen mucho el coste de mantenimiento de un gran ejército.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Quedarse sin dinero[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Si tu civilización no puede permitirse pagar los gastos que tenga, tus ciudades se declararán en "huelga", es decir, detendrán la producción de unidades y edificios hasta que hayas saneado tus finanzas. Además, es posible que llegues a perder las unidades y edificios cuyo abastecimiento no puedas permitirte. Cuando las ciudades estén en huelga, es importante que equilibres gastos e ingresos cuanto antes.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Mala gestión temprana de la riqueza[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Es posible que atravieses graves dificultades financieras al principio de la partida. Esto suele ocurrir por haber construido demasiadas ciudades o unidades sin crear primero los edificios o mejoras necesarios para que las ciudades que ya tuvieras pudieran soportar los costes de tal expansión. El resultado es que tus gastos han superado con creces a los ingresos y el tesoro se está agotando rápidamente. Hay varios pasos posibles que puedes dar para poner en orden este caos financiero:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aldeas tribales:[\BOLD] Si tienes alguna aldea tribal cerca, envíale una unidad: puede que te dé riquezas como tributo (esto es una solución "para tapar agujeros" en el mejor de los casos).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Reducir el presupuesto de investigación:[\BOLD] Reduce la cantidad que estés gastando cada turno en [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]investigación tecnológica[\LINK] mediante el botón que hay en la esquina superior izquierda de la pantalla.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construir mejoras:[\BOLD] Construye [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]villas[\LINK] y otras [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]mejoras[\LINK] que exploten los recursos rentables que se encuentren dentro de tus [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]fronteras[\LINK]: minas para obtener oro y plata, campamentos para pieles y marfil, etc. Construye carreteras para comunicar las ciudades con esos recursos.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Construir edificios:[\BOLD] Construye [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]delegaciones[\LINK] para reducir los costes de mantenimiento de las ciudades y [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]mercados[\LINK] para aumentar los ingresos. Si aún no eres capaz de construir esos edificios, dirige la [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]investigación[\LINK] a las tecnologías que permitan hacerlo. No construir estos edificios con la antelación suficiente es un problema con el que suelen encontrarse casi todos los recién llegados a Civilization IV.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Generar riqueza:[\BOLD] Si tu nivel tecnológico lo permite, puedes ordenar a las ciudades que generen riqueza en vez de nuevos edificios o unidades.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Favorecer la riqueza:[\BOLD] Pon a las ciudades en la modalidad [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]"Favorecer la riqueza"[\LINK] cuando trabajen la tierra que las rodee. Ten en cuenta, no obstante, que el gobernante de la ciudad podría no tomar las mismas decisiones que tú tomarías.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ajustar los principios:[\BOLD] Revisa la pantalla de [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]principios[\LINK] para ver si puedes reducir el coste de "mantenimiento de los principios" adoptando otros más baratos.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Destruir unidades:[\BOLD] Elimina las unidades militares sobrantes. Destruye colonos en vez de crear más ciudades que no puedas sostener.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacia:[\BOLD] Dependiendo del nivel tecnológico que poseas, es posible que obtengas oro de los vecinos, ya sea mediante intercambios O mediante amenazas.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Capturar ciudades enemigas:[\BOLD] Se suele conseguir bastante dinero con la captura de ciudades o el saqueo de mejoras.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Abandonar ciudades:[\BOLD] Si nada más funciona, siempre puedes abandonar las ciudades deficitarias. Puedes dárselas a otras civilizaciones mediante la diplomacia o bien limitarte a llevarte todas las unidades militares y esperar a que los bárbaros las capturen (no obstante, si las cosas te van ASÍ de mal, deberías pensar en la estratagema "empezar una nueva partida").

TEXT.English: [H1]Wonders[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Wonders are the spectacular buildings, inventions, and concepts that have stood the test of time and changed the world forever. The Pyramids, Notre Dame Cathedral, the Statue of Liberty and Hollywood are all examples of wonders. Wonders require much time and energy from your cities, but once completed, they provide your civilization with many benefits.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are two basic types of wonders: great wonders and national wonders.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Great wonders are unique; only one of each can be constructed during a game. For example, the Great Lighthouse is a great wonder; whoever completes it first is the only one who may possess its benefits. Great Wonders tend to be quite powerful indeed, but also extremely time-consuming to build.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]National Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] National wonders may be built once by each civilization in the game. That is, each civilization can have the Wall Street national wonder (though no civilization can have two of them). Each city may only build two national wonders, so be sure to plan ahead where you wish to put them.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Wonders are constructed in cities, like any other [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Building[\LINK]. If you can build a wonder, it will appear in your city build menu; just click on the wonder to get started. Note that only one city in your civilization can be building a single wonder at a time.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Losing the Construction Race:[\BOLD] If another civilization completes a great wonder while you are in the process of building it, your construction ceases, and a certain amount of your production efforts are converted into gold. This does not occur with national wonders, since each civilization can build its own copy of those.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders and Resources:[\BOLD] Certain resources will allow cities to produce wonders of both types at double the usual speed. For example, a civilization that has Stone connected to its [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]City Network[\LINK] can build the Pyramids at a much faster rate.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civilization Traits:[\BOLD] [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leaders[\LINK] who possess the Industrious trait build all wonders at twice the usual rate.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Wonders have a broad range of effects. Some increase productivity; others increase income from trade. Some improve research, others make your workers build improvements faster. All wonders improve their home cities [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Cultural Output[\LINK] as well as the speed at which the city generates [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Capturing Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If you capture a city with a great wonder, you gain possession of that wonder. If you capture a city with a national wonder, the national wonder is destroyed. If a city is destroyed, all wonders in that city are destroyed along with it. Great wonders can never be rebuilt once they are destroyed.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wonder Obsolescence[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some wonders can become obsolete over time. This obsolescence is caused by any civilization in the game learning a specific technology. When that occurs, the wonder's special effects vanish, but it still continues to produce culture. For example, the Great Lighthouse wonder provides a trade benefit to all coastal cities, as well as +8 culture to the city where it is constructed. The Lighthouse is rendered obsolete once the owner gains the [LINK=TECH_CORPORATION]Corporation[\LINK] technology, at which point he loses the Lighthouse trade bonus but retains its +8 cultural output.
TEXT.French: [H1]Merveilles[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Les merveilles sont les bâtiments, les inventions et les concepts qui ont surmonté l'épreuve du temps et transformé le monde. Les Pyramides, Notre Dame de Paris, la statue de la Liberté et Hollywood sont des exemples de merveilles. Les merveilles coûtent beaucoup de temps et d'énergie aux villes, mais une fois achevées, elles apportent beaucoup à votre civilisation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il y a deux grandes catégories de merveilles : les grandes merveilles et les merveilles nationales.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Grandes merveilles[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Les grandes merveilles sont uniques, et ne peuvent être construites qu'une seule fois au cours de la partie. Le grand Phare, par exemple, est une grande merveille. Le premier qui le construit est le seul à en bénéficier. Les grandes merveilles sont assez puissantes, mais très longues à construire.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Merveilles nationales[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Les merveilles nationales peuvent être construites une fois par chaque civilisation. Ainsi, toutes les civilisations peuvent avoir la merveille nationale Wall Street (mais aucune ne peut l'avoir deux fois). Une ville ne peut abriter que deux merveilles nationales, alors mieux vaut prévoir à l'avance où vous voulez les construire.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Construire des merveilles[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Les merveilles sont construites dans les villes, comme les autres [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]bâtiments[\LINK]. Lorsqu'une merveille est disponible, elle apparaît dans le menu production des villes. Cliquez dessus, et la construction démarrera. Notez qu'une merveille ne peut être construite que dans une seule de vos villes à la fois.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Perdre la course à la construction :[\BOLD] si une autre civilisation achève la construction d'une grande merveille avant vous, votre propre construction est interrompue, et une partie des unités de production déjà utilisées est transformée en or. Ceci ne peut pas se produire avec les merveilles nationales, puisque chaque civilisation peut avoir les siennes.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Merveilles et ressources :[\BOLD] certaines ressources permettent aux villes de produire les merveilles des deux catégories deux fois plus vite. Par exemple, une civilisation qui dispose des pierres reliées à son [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]réseau de villes[\LINK] peut construire les Pyramides beaucoup plus vite.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Traits des héros :[\BOLD] les [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]héros[\LINK] qui ont le trait de caractère industrieux construisent toutes les merveilles deux fois plus vite.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effets des merveilles[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les effets des merveilles sont extrêmement variés. Certaines augmentent la productivité, d'autres le revenu du commerce. Quelques-unes accélèrent la recherche, d'autres permettent à vos ouvriers de construire plus rapidement des améliorations. Toutes les merveilles améliorent aussi la [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]production culturelle[\LINK] de la ville et accélèrent la création de [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]personnages illustres[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Capturer des merveilles[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Si vous vous emparez d'une ville qui abrite une grande merveille, vous vous emparez aussi de la merveille. Si vous vous emparez d'une ville qui abrite une merveille nationale, celle-ci est détruite. Lorsqu'une ville est détruite, toutes les merveilles qu'elle abrite sont aussi anéanties. Les grandes merveilles ne peuvent pas être reconstruites après avoir été détruites.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Obsolescence des merveilles[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Certaines merveilles peuvent devenir obsolètes. Cela se produit lorsqu'une civilisation découvre une technologie particulière. A ce moment-là, tous les effets de la merveille disparaissent, sauf la production culturelle. Le grand Phare, par exemple, fournit un avantage commercial à toutes les villes côtières, ainsi qu'un bonus de +8 en culture à la ville où il est bâti. Le grand Phare devient obsolète avec la découverte par une civilisation de la technologie[LINK=TECH_CORPORATION]Sociétés commerciales[\LINK]. Le propriétaire du Phare perd alors le bénéfice commercial, mais conserve le bonus de +8 en culture.
TEXT.German: [H1]Wunder[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Wunder sind die prächtigen Gebäude, Erfindungen und Konzepte, die dem Zahn der Zeit widerstanden und die Welt für immer verändert haben. Die Pyramiden, Notre Dame, die Freiheitsstatue und Hollywood sind typische Wunder. Der Bau eines Wunders ist sehr zeit- und arbeitsaufwändig. Allerdings kann Ihre Zivilisation von einem fertig gestellten Wunder nur profitieren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es gibt zwei Arten von Wundern: Weltwunder und Nationale Wunder.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Weltwunder[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Weltwunder sind einzigartig und können im Spiel nur von einer Partei gebaut werden. Der Große Leuchtturm ist ein typisches Weltwunder. Wer ihn zuerst fertig stellt, bekommt ihn. Denken Sie daran, dass der Bau der überaus mächtigen Weltwunder sehr zeitaufwändig ist.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Nationale Wunder[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Nationale Wunder können von jeder Zivilisation gebaut werden. Die Wall Street steht also allen Parteien zum einmaligen Bau zur Verfügung. In jeder Stadt können maximal zwei Nationale Wunder gebaut werden. Sie sollten sich vorher also genau überlegen, wo Sie diese errichten möchten.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Bau von Wundern[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Wunder werden wie alle anderen [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Gebäude[\LINK] in Städten errichtet. Können Sie ein Wunder bauen, erscheint dieses im Gebäude-Menü. Nach einem Klick auf das Wunder beginnen Ihre Untertanen mit den Bauarbeiten. Denken Sie daran, dass jede Stadt nur an einem Wunder arbeiten kann.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wettlauf mit der Zeit:[\BOLD] Stellt eine andere Zivilisation ein Weltwunder fertig, legen ihre Bautrupps die Arbeit nieder und Sie erhalten eine finanzielle Entschädigung für ihre bisherigen Bemühungen. Dies gilt NICHT für nationale Wunder, da jede Zivilisation ihr eigene Kopie davon bauen kann.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wunder und Ressourcen:[\BOLD] Bestimmte Ressourcen erlauben es einer Stadt, Wunder mit doppelter Geschwindigkeit zu produzieren. Eine Zivilisation, in deren [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]Städtenetz[\LINK] Steine vorhanden sind, kann beispielsweise die Pyramiden weitaus schneller bauen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Eigenschaften:[\BOLD] [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Staatsoberhäupter[\LINK] mit der Eigenschaft industriell bauen alle Wunder doppelt so schnell.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Auswirkungen der Wunder[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Einige Wunder steigern die Produktivität, andere das Handelseinkommen, wieder andere beschleunigen die Forschung und die Modernisierung Ihrer Zivilisation. Viele Wunder verbessern darüber hinaus den [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Kulturwert[\LINK] einer Stadt und fördern die Entstehung [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Großer Persönlichkeiten[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Eroberung von Wundern[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Erobern Sie eine Stadt mit einem Weltwunder, geht dieses in Ihren Besitz über. Nationale Wunder werden bei der Einnahme einer Stadt zerstört. Zerstören Sie eine Stadt, sind auch deren Wunder verloren. Große Wunder können nicht neu aufgebaut werden, wenn sie einmal zerstört wurden.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Überflüssige Wunder[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Einige Wunder werden überflüssig, wenn eine Zivilisation eine bestimmte Technologie entdeckt hat. Ist dies der Fall, beeinflusst das jeweilige Wunder nur noch die Kultur einer Zivilisation. Nehmen wir das Wunder des Großen Leuchtturms als Beispiel. Er verschafft allen Küstenstädten einen Handelsbonus und der Stadt, in der er gebaut wurde, einen Kulturbonus (+8). Erfindet eine Zivilisation die [LINK=TECH_CORPORATION]Kapitalgesellschaft[\LINK], geht der Handelsbonus verloren, nicht aber der Kulturbonus.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Meraviglie[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Le Meraviglie sono edifici spettacolari, invenzioni e idee che hanno sfidato il tempo e cambiato il mondo per sempre. Le Piramidi, la Cattedrale di Notre Dame, la Statua della Libertà e Hollywood sono esempi di meraviglie. Le Meraviglie chiedono molto, in termini di tempo ed energia, alle città che le costruiscono, ma una volta portate a termine procurano molti benefici.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ci sono due tipi di Meraviglie: Grandi Meraviglie e Meraviglie Nazionali.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Grandi Meraviglie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Le Grandi Meraviglie sono uniche; nel corso di una partita ne può essere costruita solo una. Ad esempio, il Grande Faro è una Grande Meraviglia: chiunque lo costruisca per primo è anche l'unico a trarre vantaggio dai suoi benefici. Le grandi meraviglie tendono ad essere piuttosto potenti, ma estremamente lunghe da costruire.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Meraviglie Nazionali[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Le Meraviglie Nazionali possono essere costruite una sola volta da ciascuna civiltà nel corso di una partita. Questo vuol dire che ogni civiltà può avere la Meraviglia Nazionale di Wall Street (ma nessuna civiltà può averne due). Ogni città può costruire solo due Meraviglie Nazionali, quindi sinceratevi di pianificare per tempo dove volete collocarle.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Costruzione delle Meraviglie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Le Meraviglie vengono costruite all'interno delle città, come qualunque altro [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]edificio[\LINK]. Se puoi costruire una Meraviglia, essa apparirà nel menu di costruzione della città: non devi far altro che cliccare sulla Meraviglia per dare inizio alla sua costruzione. Ricordati che la stessa Meraviglia può essere costruita solo da una città alla volta nell'ambito della stessa civiltà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Perdere nella corsa per la costruzione di una Meraviglia:[\BOLD] se un'altra civiltà costruisce una Grande Meraviglia mentre la tua sta ancora lavorandoci, la tua costruzione viene interrotta, e parte degli sforzi produttivi viene convertita in oro. Questa regola non vale per le Meraviglie Nazionali, dal momento che ogni civiltà può costruirsi la propria.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Meraviglie e Risorse:[\BOLD] alcune risorse consentono alle città di produrre Meraviglie di entrambi i tipi (grandi e nazionali) al doppio della velocità. Ad esempio, una civiltà che ha la pietra collegata alla sua [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]rete cittadina[\LINK] può costruire le Piramidi a un ritmo molto più elevato.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Punti di forza della civiltà:[\BOLD] [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leader[\LINK] dal carattere industrioso costruiscono tutte le Meraviglie due volte più rapidamente degli altri.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effetti delle Meraviglie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le Meraviglie hanno diversi effetti sul gioco. Alcune aumentano la produttività, altre le rendite degli scambi, altre potenziano la ricerca, altre ancora fanno sì che i lavoratori costruiscano più rapidamente i miglioramenti. Tutte le Meraviglie contribuiscono ad elevare la [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]produzione culturale[\LINK] della città in cui sono costruite, così come il ritmo con cui la città produce [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Grandi Personaggi[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Conquista di Meraviglie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Se conquisti una Grande Meraviglia, entri in possesso di quella meraviglia. Se conquisti una città con una Meraviglia Nazionale, quest'ultima viene distrutta. Se una città viene distrutta, con lei vengono rase al suolo tutte le Meraviglie al suo interno. Le Grandi Meraviglie non possono essere ricostruite una volta distrutte.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Obsolescenza delle Meraviglie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Alcune Meraviglie possono diventare obsolete nel corso del tempo; l'obsolescenza è causata dalla scoperta, da parte di qualunque civiltà, anche quella che la possiede, di una specifica tecnologia. Quando questo avviene, si perdono i benefici speciali della Meraviglia, che continua comunque a produrre cultura. Ad esempio, il Grande Faro fornisce un bonus negli scambi a tutte le città costiere, e +8 punti cultura alla città che l'ha costruito. Il Grande Faro è reso obsoleto una volta che il suo possessore scopre la [LINK=TECH_CORPORATION]Corporazione[\LINK]; perde così il bonus commerciale ma mantiene quello di +8 per la produzione di cultura.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Maravillas[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Las maravillas son edificios, inventos y conceptos espectaculares que han resistido el paso del tiempo y cambiado el mundo para siempre. Las Pirámides, la catedral de Notre Dame, la Estatua de la Libertad y Hollywood son ejemplos de tales maravillas. Éstas le exigen mucho tiempo y energía a las ciudades pero, una vez construidas, le proporcionan a tu civilización muchos beneficios.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hay dos tipos básicos de maravillas: las grandes maravillas y las maravillas nacionales.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Grandes maravillas[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Las grandes maravillas son únicas y solo puede construirse una de cada por partida. Por ejemplo, el Gran Faro es una gran maravilla, y quien lo complete primero será el único en obtener sus beneficios. Las grandes maravillas suelen ser muy poderosas, pero construirlas también consume mucho tiempo.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Maravillas nacionales[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Cada una de las civilizaciones en juego puede construir una de las maravillas nacionales. Es decir, cada civilización puede tener la maravilla nacional de Wall Street (aunque ninguna civilización puede tener dos de ellas). Cada ciudad solo puede construir dos maravillas nacionales, así que asegúrate de planificar con antelación dónde deseas ponerlas.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Construir maravillas[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] Las maravillas se construyen en las ciudades, como cualquier otro [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]edificio[\LINK]. Cuando puedas construir una maravilla, ésta aparecerá en el menú de construcción de la ciudad. Basta con que hagas clic en la maravilla para empezar. Ten en cuenta que solo puede haber una ciudad de tu civilización construyendo una maravilla a la vez.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Perder la carrera de la construcción:[\BOLD] Si otra civilización completa una gran maravilla mientras tú estás en el proceso de construirla, tu construcción se detendrá y parte de tus esfuerzos se convertirán en una cierta cantidad de oro. Esto no ocurre con las maravillas nacionales, ya que cada civilización puede construir su propia copia de ella.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Maravillas y recursos:[\BOLD] Ciertos recursos permitirán que las ciudades construyan maravillas de ambos tipos al doble de la velocidad normal. Por ejemplo, una civilización que tenga piedra comunicada con su [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]red de ciudades[\LINK] puede construir las Pirámides a una velocidad mucho mayor.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Rasgos de la civilización:[\BOLD] Los [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]líderes[\LINK] que tengan el rasgo de diligente construirán todas las maravillas al doble del ritmo normal.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Efectos de las maravillas[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Las maravillas tienen un gran abanico de efectos. Algunas aumentan la productividad mientras que otras incrementan los ingresos provenientes del intercambio. También las hay que benefician a la investigación o que hacen que los trabajadores construyan mejoras más rápido. Todas las maravillas mejoran la [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]producción cultural[\LINK] de la ciudad en la que se encuentran así como la velocidad a la que ésta genera [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]grandes personajes[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Capturar maravillas[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Si capturas una ciudad con una gran maravilla, adquieres la posesión de tal maravilla. Si capturas una ciudad con una maravilla nacional, dicha maravilla quedará destruida. Si destruyes una ciudad, todas las maravillas que haya en ella se destruirán a la vez. Las grandes maravillas nunca podrán reconstruirse tras su destrucción.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Maravillas obsoletas[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Algunas maravillas pueden llegar a quedar obsoletas con el tiempo. Dicha obsolescencia la causa la adquisición de una tecnología determinada por parte de cualquier civilización del juego. Cuando eso ocurra, los efectos especiales de la maravilla se perderán, pero ésta seguirá generando cultura. Por ejemplo, la maravilla del Gran Faro proporciona un beneficio al intercambio en todas las ciudades costeras, así como un +8 en cultura a la ciudad en la que se construya. El Faro queda obsoleto cuando su propietario obtiene la tecnología de la [LINK=TECH_CORPORATION]Corporación[\LINK]. A partir de entonces, se pierde la bonificación comercial que proporciona, aunque no el +8 de producción cultural.

TEXT.English: For every Victory Resource your civilization controls you will receive 10 Victory points per turn.
TEXT.French: Vous recevez 10 points de victoire par tour pour chaque ressource de victoire que votre civilisation contrôle.

TEXT.Spanish: Por cada recurso para la victoria que controle tu civilización recibirás 10 puntos de victoria por turno.

TEXT.English: [H1]10 FAQs before Declaring a War[\H1][PARAGRAPH:1]- by [BOLD]maltz[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It is really hard to write another article in this forum, as all of the necessary knowledges have been covered in many great guides and analyses. The best I can do is try a summary of a specific topic.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I started playing Civ4 as a peace lover, but now I am clearly a warmonger who is "forced to win early" by the game mechanism. The game really favors a warmonger. So, please allow me to summarize my war experiences into "10 FAQS that I ask myself before declaring a war".[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q1: What do I gain from this war?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Although not every human action carries a purpose, theoretically they should. Contemporary artists paint craps because they want to paint craps to disturb you.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Every war should serve a purpose, too. For example:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Secure a large interior of my territory[NEWLINE]- Gain a few precious resources that I don't own[NEWLINE]- Kill off a great threat in the future[NEWLINE]- Put down a warmonger that may backstab me, before it gets a chance[NEWLINE]- Simply expanding my empire[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A competent warhead should have a clear goal in mind. Not just sending out his troops to "punish a bugger". That's what a "jerk" would do.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q2: What do I do AFTER the war?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It never hurts to plan one, a few, or many steps further, if you have extra time before the action is due. What will I do after the war For example:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Continue the war on the next target, if I still have the military lead[NEWLINE]- Call it a day and enter a massive 500-year peaceful growth period[NEWLINE]- Give some distant territory to a weak friend to create a buffer[NEWLINE]- Put research to 0% and let scientists to handle "Iron Working".[NEWLINE]- Ask for peace money when my loss is enough, and let Monty continue my war.[NEWLINE]- Remember to put culture slider back to 0%.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There are various things to think of, some big, some trivial.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q3: Could I have allies to help me, or the enemy?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Diplomacy usually decides the war outcome. A third party can turn the tide of war completely.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Obviously, you want to have all the help you could obtain, and eliminate all the backstabs you may receive. All of the Civs that are friendly with you are possible helps, and they are usually willing to join your war after you declare it. The aggressive / fanatic ones may start the war for you if your price is right. All of the Civs that are friendly to your enemy are going to do the same for them, though.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Shouldn't you do something to prevent that from happening Actually, the solution is easy. You may bribe another Civ to attack your enemy's potential ally. You may bribe your enemy's potential ally to attack somebody else. Just to keep them busy, and they can't be possibly helping your enemy while they need help themselves. Note that a warmonger can be anybody's friend, so it is especially important to bribe warmongers to go after someone before your war, or simply bribe them to help you. The good thing is that the AIs aren't very smart at bribing others to war, so you don't have to be over-cautious.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]If you have eliminated all possible helps from your enemy, you already declare the war at the "worst" situation possible, because it can't get worse! If you are already at an advantage at this worst possible situation, then clearly you can't lose - only to win faster by pulling in a friend.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Generally, it is a good practice to stir a world war every time you are going to war. While everybody is busy with everybody, your target losses all potential helps. I am still attacked when I am weak, but I have never been backstabbed when I am no longer weak, but vulnerable during a war. I always make muscle man show their back to me before I draw my knife.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q4: Could I annoy my friends, or other Civs by this war?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Certainly your target is gonna hate you, but how about your friends and other neutral Civs I have to check the relationship of my targets to other Civs. If they are at Pleased or Friendly, then certainly will get "You declared war to our friend!" modifier. This can potentially spoil a Friendly relationship to Pleased, a Pleased to Cautious, or Cautious to Annoyed. The consequence may be very bad.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]To prevent this, you can spoil their relationship first. For example, A is your target, and B is your friend. A and B are friends, too. If you ask A to attack B's friend, C, then B is going to dislike A a little more. If that makes B Cautious to A, then you won't get any white eye from B when you declare war on A.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The good thing is, -1 in most cases doesn't change anything. So you don't have to worry that much.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some people think they should purposely annoy the enemy so they will declare war on themselves. This usually doesn't work, as the AIs evaluates the power difference pretty much. If you are weak, you don't have to purposely annoy them, and they will come after you. If you are powerful, no matter how many nukes you drop on their head, they swallow the fallout and tears.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Generally speaking, during a conquest it is unavoidable that eventually you will annoy all of the Civs by invading multiple Civs in the past. It is OK. Up to a point, you will be powerful enough that nobody dares to declare war on you. You can also allign your religion with them, sell them your extra resources, and give them little helps to maintain the relationship at Pleased. And, since you still make everybody busy before you draw out your knife, they still can't help each other against you.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q5: Could I have declared this war 100 years earlier?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]My original Q5 was "Could I have avoided this war" but I found it too lame. Of course I want to war in Civ4 because it makes me win much faster! I have to be honest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Could I have declared this war 100 years earlier Sometimes yes! I am such a chicken that sometimes I want to make sure everything is safe - but by waiting I might make myself less safe. The earlier I become aggressive, the more advantages I get. I don't have to get everything prepared sometimes, because neither is my enemy. At times, I give up the past hour of gameplay, and start the war 100 years ealier. I win; I feel very happy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]***[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In the first 5 FAQs I covered the preparation/abstract aspects of war. In the next 5 FAQs I will get into some practical details.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q6: Is my attack route fool-proof?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]An attack route is the plan of army advance, where my invading stack enters the unfriendly territory, where I camp at each turn, and how I carry on my attack to the next city. A forest, a river, or a hill can all make a huge difference.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It will be the best if I have an active update of what's happening in the enemy's territory. For example, if I own a holy city of a religion, I will probably get an Open Border well beforehand, and spread my "professional" missionaries to my future opponent's cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]If I don't have a holy city, I can simply ask for an Open border, and send out many faster, less powerful units (scouts, chariots) for a latest update. As soon as the war is declared, these scouts will be repelled from the enemy territory, so they can either have a free return ticket, or end up in nowhere.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With a significant military advantage, it is usually good to divide your huge army up, plan multiple attack routes from different entries, and devour several AIs cities all at once. However, against smarter human opponents, it is usually wise to have an invincible stack of death. When you enter an enemy's territory, it is possible for your opponent to concentrate their counterattack and eliminate your divided invading forces with their relative mobility. That brings up the next question:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q7: How do I deal with a counterattack stack?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]If your target is not too weak, it is very likely that there will be a counterattck stack organized, and heads towards your territory. Even if your target is weak, it might still send out a few horse riders to pillage your improvements to distract you.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Do you have enough home defense to deal with a counterattack stack, even just a few horse archers Do you have fast unit to hunt down their fast unit Do you have spears to poke at the horses In my experience, about 20% of my total mobilized army are actually used for homeland defense / fortify new acquired territory. In multiplayer situations this ratio will go much higher, because smarter human players concentrate their attacks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Another very common phenomenon is to be showered by a large number of catapults when you advance into enemy territory. There is really no way to prevent this. You need to have more units in that stack to dilute the splash colleteral damage. Some people say you can split your stack, but I don't think it is a good idea. If I am the defender, I can easily concentrate my catapult shower on half your stack, and use all of my defending forces to kill off half of your army. By the time your intact, the-other half arrives at my castle gate, my forces have returned and started healing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Right after taking a city, it might be worthwhile waiting for the wounded troops to heal, if lots of healing is needed. An army at half of its strength is really inviting a crushing defeat.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Following the catapult bombardment, the enemy might follow up with a mixture of other spare units. You may think AI is stupid to commite suicide this way, but those counter attacks can be devastating if you don't have a balanced stack. If you don't have elephants/spears in your invading stack, your melee units might get slaughtered by horses. It is wise to carry a few defensive units in the same stack, just for the purpose of insurance. Plus, they can help you afterwards...[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q8: Did I forget the garrison troops?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]You might be able to take the city, but you will need troops to defend it. Chance is the enemy's culture border still enables them to take the city back in 1 turn, if your new city is not properly defended. You must know by now that good garrison troops are very different from good attack troops. Archery + Spears/Elephant are very good garrison troops; the AI love to have them, too.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]One of my common mistakes is I "barely made it", so I have one very weak unit in the new city, and I don't have any units that can move in to help. The result is usually I lose the new city and the wounded unit to a very weak counter attack force. The AIs will hunt down each one of your weak units, especially when they can get a city back in the meantime.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]You don't want to leave a portion of assault troops in each of your new cities, to weaken your invasion as you go on. It might be too late to start producing garrison troops after your war declaration.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q9: Did I forget to move a unit somewhere?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This is more of a gameplay aspect. When a war gets big, it is easy (at least for me) to forget a few units that has been previously assigned on garrison purpose, but no longer needed. When I can locate them (through the military advisor) and pull them to the front, my battle often becomes much easier.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Q10: Am I on my way to my next military tech lead?[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Not really an FAQ - I just include this for morale boosting purpose. When you hack down archers with maceman, you should be thinking of blasting longbowman with gernadiers. When that comes true, you should be thinking of the cheerful gunpowder explosion echos made by cavalry and cannons. After that, it is probably sniping grenadiers with infatry rifles. You are always creating a military lead, because the AI never stops trying to catch up. After a certain point, you are just going to wipe out the rest of the AIs in a short period of time, if you haven't accidently cross over the domination victory threshold.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]***[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]May I conclude this article with a popular quote from Sun Tze:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]"Knowing your enemy and yourself, you can fight 100 battles without dire danger."[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The key of a war is to avoid losing. If you can smell the war not approaching your victory, then you better quit it as soon as possible. In order to smell it, you need knowledge of the situation. If you don't suffer huge defeat, naturally over time you will get a few chances to crush the enemy. If you succeed at doing that, you win! In Civ4 the wars are much eaiser, so usually you immediately win after a little planning.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A popular misconception of this quote turns the latter part into "you can fight 100 battles without a loss." This is definitely naive. You can still lose, because there is luck, competent enemy commanders, and endless suicide bombers (catapults). However, with enough knowledge of the situation, you may lose, but you are not exhausted. You can still regroup, tell yourself there are still lots of hope, and come back for the eventual win, while your enemy feels tired and whines "What is war good for? Absolutely nothing!"

[H1]A Guide to Civics[\H1][PARAGRAPH:1]- by [BOLD]Pfeffersack[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The intention of this article is to give hints and tips about when and how to use the different Civics in Civilization 4.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For each civic there is a note on availability, followed by a short description of the effects/costs, diplomatic implications, comments on synergy with other game elements (other civics, leader traits, buildings, game settings, common strategies) and a final summary on the usefulness of the civic.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Any Feedback is highly appreciated and the guide will be updated with comments and strategies people post here (credits will be given here in the first post).My (high) aim is to provide a comprehensive database on the complex subject of civics.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Additional Credits for contributing interesting aspects, strategies and correcting inadequate information: genjiboy, Heroes, Krikkitone, Orca, Samson.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][H2]Some General Thoughts on Civics in Civ4[\H2][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Maintenance[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Note: Roland Johansen has done a great article about civic upkeep (http://www.civfanatics.com/civ4/strategy/civic_upkeep.php).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Civics are divided into 4 upkeep categories: no, low, medium and high. As a very rough rule of thumb you will pay 0 for zero, x for low, 1,5-2x for medium and 2-3x for high upkeep civics.The exact values depend on your number of cities and your population.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With a growing empire and increasing inflation, civic upkeep can really drain from your treasury. If you consider which civics to use, always keep the upkeep as an additional factor in mind - if you are unsure which civic is the better one, then the cheaper one is usually the better idea. Perhaps with the exception of Environmentalism, all the high-upkeep civics offer strong advantages. But if go for them, you should check if you can really use them to a certain extent - running Vassalage only pays if you build enough units, while Organized Religion is a waste if you are busy to build up your army.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Spiritual[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I haven't mentioned spiritual as a factor in most of the strategy/synergy sections (with Slavery and Nationalism as exceptions; for why see the civic article) for one reason - it is just plain useful to civics in general. The smooth government transition without anarchy transforms in two advantages: The freedom to change [BOLD]when[\BOLD] and [BOLD]as often as necessary[\BOLD].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]When[\BOLD] just means the independence of things as wars, golden age or wonder races. Without interfering anarchy, there is no need to wait with a revolution. If a better option shows up, switch (to be correct, there is still a restriction regarding minimum time between two revolutions, but that's only rarely a real problem).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The second benefit is the fact that you don't have to think about [BOLD]if switching (and eventually switching back again soon) is worth the anarchy[\BOLD]. Without the spiritual trait, you have to keep an eye on the number of switches you make in a game - if you accumulate to many anarchy turns over time, it may hurt your progress. Sometimes the anarchy just eats up the small advantage the new civic would give you, especially if the benefits are needed only temporarily (for example, "hurry civics" as Slavery or Universal Suffrage, the "draft civic" Nationalism or Bureaucracy, if you go for a wonder in your capital) - then you will either drop the switch altogether or at least delay it to make a "big revolution" (see below for this strategy for non-spiritual civs). Spirituals effect also tends to rise in Epic or Marathon games.Not so much by the fact the anarchy period is at minimum 2 turns and can easily scale up to 4 (this is counterbalanced by every turn being "less" valuable), but because unit movement isn't modified - a "quick" switch to Slavery and Nationalism without Spiritual to stop an enemy attack will need three turns(!) to show an effect; three turns in which moreover everything in your empire stands still.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Organized[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The organized trait is the second one which has an direct impact on civics.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Organized shifts the balance towards the civics with (higher) maintenance, which are usually the ones with a greater impact and stronger effect...and those suited for a more aggressive and (regarding your empires population) repressive playing style.If you compare a (war-monger) combination of Police State, Vassalage, Caste System, Mercantilism and Theocracy with for example Universal Suffrage, Free Speech, Emancipation, State Property and Free Religion (large empire going for cottages), you will clearly see the different impact of Organized.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]To sum up, the effect here can be significant (if you adopt your general "big plan") to meaningless (if you don't). That's also the reason why Organized is usually rated as the weakest trait - however, if at all, that's only partly true.For the civic effect depending on the playing style yes, but you also get cheaper Lighthouses and more important Courthouses - both directing to faster expansion. Not a bad thing in Civ4.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]When to change?[\BOLD] (applies mainly for non-spiritual civs)[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The question is nearly as difficult as the one dealing with what to change. As usually there is not a single correct answer. You have to consider different situations and factors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]First of all it is important to distinguish the first, initial change in a civic column from later changes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In case of the [BOLD]initial change[\BOLD], the straight advice in most of the cases is simply: Change as soon as it possible without. The initial civics do nothing for you except draining low maintenance. Sure, most of the civics you will get first access to in the different columns (Hereditary Rule, Bureaucracy/Vassalage, Slavery/Caste System, Mercantilism and Organized Religion) have a higher upkeep, but the give you some advantage and the real cost for this advantage is lower (because you have to subtract one maintenance level in your calculation - the level you have to pay for the starters anyway!)[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Things are more complicated when [BOLD]changing from a "real" civic to another[\BOLD]. Again, switching ASAP is usually not a bad idea - simply because getting a better civic sooner is better and because in a growing economy a turn of anarchy becomes more and more expensive, if the game progresses.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]However, some circumstances might make a delayed revolution a better idea. It is for example not a good idea to switch during a golden age (however, the mistake would rather triggering the Golden Age before the switch in most cases) or when you need every turn in a wonder race or for building units in a case of emergency (of course with the exception of a switch to something which helps especially in those situations).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Even if no such special situation makes waiting worth, the concept of "big revolutions" can do so. Instead of switching only one civic in a revolution, you can change up to 5. The anarchy penalty rises too, but not in linear way. You can switch up to 3 civics at one time and will still suffer only one turn anarchy. So you can minimize the turns lost to anarchy if you wait for example a few turns to get another tech which enables a new civic.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And last but not least there may be economic reasons - don't underestimate the pressure high cost civics can lay on your economy. Especially when having the concept of a big revolution in mind, it might be tempting to make a big change - for example when going to war, switching from low cost "peace" civics to the repressive ones. Make sure you have a healthy economy, a full treasury or a Great Merchant around. Otherwise you might come into trouble soon. Wars are already expensive in Civ4 without the political dimension (more units to support, units must be supplied in enemy lands, enemies eventually pillaging the land, unit upgrades, bribery for allies etc.), so those extra civic costs might lead to strikes or at least a serious drop in your research efforts. A bad move here can be devastating, since you have to wait a few turns to be able to correct it again.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][H2]The Government Column[\H2][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Special notes: The special thing about this column is that you can get access to all civics very early - if you are willing and lucky enough to build "The Pyramids". The immediate availability of all the civics of course change their relative values, so my rather general advices might fail here.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And there is a second special thing about it...21 out of 26 leaders have their favorite civic inside this column, so your decision here can have an important influence on how getting along with the other leaders...[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hereditary Rule[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Prerequisite/availability:[\BOLD] Monarchy (classic era)[NEWLINE][BOLD]Effect:[\BOLD] +1 happiness per military unit inside a city[NEWLINE][BOLD]Upkeep:[\BOLD] Medium[NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomatic relations bonus with:[\BOLD] Alexander, Catherine, Hatshepsut, Huayna Capac, Kublai Khan and Louis XIV.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Synergy/strategies:[\BOLD] Organized, Vassalage, Nationalism, Theocracy, OCC, cold or general defensive wars (especially AW), ressource-scarce maps[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Summary:[\BOLD] The good old military police and better than ever before. No more upper limit. But it comes now with a hefty price, too. Beside the unit upkeep, the civic itself will cost you a substantial sum to maintain. Nearly every other way to produce happiness will be cheaper, but sometimes there is no other way to stay in the "yellow faces" (mainly because of few religions and/or resources).Then it is the right choice, because avoiding unhappy citizens is a high-priority goal. And unless you own the Pyramids, it is the best what you can get for a long time. Otherwise, try to leave it ASAP...if you get access to a new government civic, check if you really need HR any more. If most of the happiness is lost due overflow, consider switching immediately. Even if you can live with the costs (which indeed tend to become less of a problem, if your cities grow really big), you will at least miss the benefits of Universal Suffrage, as soon as it becomes available.[NEWLINE]On the diplomatic table, the civic puts you at good relations (usually a permanent + of 1-3, depending on how long you are in the civic and on how keen the leader is about foreign politics) with 6 other leaders...that's more than with any other civic![NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Representation[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prerequisite/availability:[\BOLD] Constitution (renaissance era)[NEWLINE][BOLD]Effect:[\BOLD] Every specialist (including settled down 'super-specialists') yields 3 extra research; the biggest 5 (or 6...I'm unsure if this a flat number or something dependent on map size) cities in your empire get 3 extra happiness.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Upkeep:[\BOLD] Low[NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomatic relations bonus with:[\BOLD] Bismarck, Cyrus, Caesar, Napoleon, Victoria[NEWLINE][BOLD]Synergy/strategies:[\BOLD] [BOLD]Caste System[\BOLD], [BOLD]Mercantilism[\BOLD], Pacifism, Philosophical, Organized, OCC - FCC, smaller maps(?),GP-based strategies.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Summary:[\BOLD] Representation is the second available choice in the government column and it can be very useful in different situations.
